t: Numbers 24
The Prophecy from Peor
When*p Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord*s to bless Israel, he did not go as at other times to seek omens but he set his face toward the wilderness.
And Balaam lifted up his eyes and saw Israel camping tribe by tribe; and the Spirit of God came upon him.
He took up his discourse and said, “The*pn oracle of Balaam the son of Beor, And*ln the oracle of the man whose eye is opened;
The*ln oracle of him who hears the words of God, Who*ln sees the vision of the Almighty, Falling*ln down, yet having his eyes uncovered,
How*ln fair are your tents, O Jacob, Your*ln dwellings, O Israel!
Like*ln valleys that stretch out, Like*ln gardens beside the river, Like*ln aloes planted by the Lord,*s Like*ln cedars beside the waters.
Water*ln will flow from his buckets, And*ln his seed will*i be*i by many waters, And*ln his king shall be higher than Agag, And*ln his kingdom shall be exalted.

God*ln brings him out of Egypt, He*ln is for him like the horns of the wild ox. He*ln will devour the nations who*i are*i his adversaries, And*ln will crush their bones in pieces, And*ln shatter them*i with his arrows.
He*ln couches, he lies down as a lion, And*ln as a lion, who dares rouse him? Blessed*ln is everyone who blesses you, And*ln cursed is everyone who curses you.”

Then*p Balak’s anger burned against Balaam, and he struck his hands together; and Balak said to Balaam, “I called you to curse my enemies, but behold, you have persisted in blessing them these three times!
Therefore, flee to your place now. I said I would honor you greatly, but behold, the Lord*s has held you back from honor.”
Balaam said to Balak, “Did I not tell your messengers whom you had sent to me, saying,

‘Though Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not do anything contrary to the command of the Lord,*s either good or bad, of my own accord. What the Lord*s speaks, that I will speak’?
And now, behold, I am going to my people; come, and*i I will advise you what this people will do to your people in the days to come.”
He*p took up his discourse and said, “The*pn oracle of Balaam the son of Beor, And*ln the oracle of the man whose eye is opened,
The*ln oracle of him who hears the words of God, And*ln knows the knowledge of the Most High, Who*ln sees the vision of the Almighty, Falling*ln down, yet having his eyes uncovered.

I*ln see him, but not now; I*ln behold him, but not near; A*ln star shall come forth from Jacob, A*ln scepter shall rise from Israel, And*ln shall crush through the forehead of Moab, And*ln tear down all the sons of Sheth.
Edom*ln shall be a possession, Seir,*ln its enemies, also will be a possession, While*ln Israel performs valiantly.
One*ln from Jacob shall have dominion, And*ln will destroy the remnant from the city.”
And*p he looked at Amalek and took up his discourse and said, “Amalek*pn was the first of the nations, But*ln his end shall*i be*i destruction.”
And*p he looked at the Kenite, and took up his discourse and said, “Your*pn dwelling place is enduring, And*ln your nest is set in the cliff.
Nevertheless*ln Kain will be consumed; How*ln long will Asshur keep you captive?”
Then*p he took up his discourse and said, “Alas,*pn who can live except God has ordained it?
But*ln ships shall*i come*i from the coast of Kittim, And*ln they shall afflict Asshur and will afflict Eber; So*ln they also will*i come*i to destruction.”
Then*p Balaam arose and departed and returned to his place, and Balak also went his way.
